text: In case you don't like the weird way to convert with f-strings/strip to manage bytes, here is another version: bytes_header = int.to_bytes(len(bytes_message), HEADER_LENTH, "big") int_header = int.from_bytes(bytes_header, "big")  And to convert utf8-string to bytes: bytes_data = bytes(data, "utf-8") utf8_data = bytes_data.decode("utf-8")

clients[notified_socket]                                        print(f"Received message from {user['data'].decode('utf-8')}: {message['data'].decode('utf-8')}")              for clients_socket in author: @ScottUlmer
text: Hey I found a way to attach it into a UI. The biggest "issue" is that I had to break your While True and instead had it look for new messages every 1 second. While there might be some lag (literally up to a second), I find this more than useful to people who would be following these tutorials.  Just so you know I simply took your code and modified it to work with a .ui file. Using a .ui with Qt Designer is very user-friendly. If you are interested in what I made let me know.

text: Great vid as always, also random 5cent for life improvement : i highly recommend "cmder" if you're looking for a command console that doesn't look like crap, plus you can do all the fancy things like split the console so that you can see your client and servers without having 3 cmd laying around. bonus point : it looks gorgeous  (install either via chocolatey cinst -y cmder or go to cmder.net)
